Bottom line: For a small junior like Wishbone, winning a high-quality, strategically located, contested tenement like E45/7169 is a major value-add — both as a real exploration asset and as a market/strategic signal. In Paterson terms, it could be as significant as a multi-million-dollar exploration licence with high discovery upside.

1. Strategic Significance of E45/7169 Aspect	Importance Location relative to Telfer	The tenement is only 25 km NW of Telfer, one of Australia’s largest gold-copper mines. Being adjacent to this world-class corridor gives Wishbone proximity to proven ore systems, which is highly strategic for early-stage explorers. Contiguity with existing projects	E45/7169 can be added to existing access agreements and heritage arrangements with Greatland Gold. This creates a contiguous operational area for Wishbone, simplifying logistics, approvals, and permitting. Greenfield potential	The land has no documented historic mining or drilling, meaning Wishbone can define targets without legacy constraints, giving them first-mover advantage. 2. Value Added to Wishbone A. Portfolio Expansion & Optionality In exploration, size and continuity of tenement holdings are valuable because: It increases the number of drill targets. It allows for regional-scale geological modelling, improving targeting efficiency. It strengthens negotiating power for joint ventures or partnerships. Adding E45/7169 effectively grows Wishbone’s Paterson footprint by 67 km², which is significant for a junior with an existing ~Red Setter and nearby Cottesloe portfolio. B. Access to Strategic Infrastructure Proximity to Telfer and inclusion in the Greatland Gold access agreement reduces: Mobilisation and drill costs Regulatory friction Community and heritage engagement overheads This is a substantial operational and cost advantage compared to starting on completely greenfield, unaccessed land. C. Exploration Upside Underexplored, structurally prospective ground is rare in the Paterson Province, especially close to Telfer. Securing this land gives Wishbone: Potential for new high-grade discoveries Targets that are analogous to Telfer/Havieron systems First rights to drill and report results, giving a newsflow and market visibility advantage D. Market/Investor Perception Winning a contested ballot against larger companies (like Antipa Minerals) sends a strong signal to investors and the market: Wishbone is a serious player in the Paterson Province They are capable of competing for premium ground This can increase investor confidence, potentially boosting share value, capital raising ability, and strategic partnerships. 3. Strategic Summary Strategic Benefit	Details Geological leverage	Access to underexplored land near world-class deposits (Telfer) Operational efficiency	Contiguous tenement with existing access and heritage agreements Exploration optionality	Greenfield targets with first-mover advantage Market perception	Winning over larger competitors validates capability and raises profile Portfolio value increase	Adds high-potential ground that could materially impact future valuation if targets are successful

data.author: MH01
data.content: Lol. The pumping pumpy crowd is back after an RNS about a tenement. Easily pleased. This like many is a pump and dump.

Larger companies may overextend their applications: Sometimes bigger explorers apply for many blocks at once, reducing focus on any single one — smaller specialists can focus on one prime block. Government policy preference: WA occasionally supports diversifying explorers to encourage innovation and discovery in greenfield areas rather than letting established miners dominate. ✅ Summary E45/7169 was awarded via a contested ballot, not based on company size or wealth. Wishbone qualified because it has technical experience, financial capacity, and existing heritage/access agreements. Large competitors like Antipa Minerals had no advantage in the ballot system, which is designed to give smaller explorers a fair chance. This approach benefits WA exploration by getting small, nimble explorers onto greenfield ground, which often leads to discoveries that large miners later develop.

1. How the WA Government Awards Contested Exploration Licences For new mineral exploration licence applications on Crown land (like E45/7169), the Department of Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety (DMIRS) uses a ballot system when multiple parties apply for the same ground: Applications Submitted: Companies lodge an exploration licence application for the same block. Eligibility Assessment: DMIRS checks that applicants meet minimum criteria: Financial capacity to explore (not necessarily huge reserves of cash, just ability to carry out a reasonable program) Technical competence / previous exploration experience Compliance with regulatory requirements (e.g., environmental and heritage approvals) Ballot Process (Contested Lots): If multiple eligible parties apply, the licence may be awarded via a random ballot, rather than competitive bidding. This is explicitly to give smaller explorers a fair chance at high-potential ground, avoiding monopoly by large incumbents. In short: the process is legally randomized, not purely meritocratic by company size or market cap. Reference: DMIRS WA Mineral Titles Bulletin 2. Why Wishbone Was Eligible and Awarded E45/7169 Meets all eligibility criteria: Wishbone has existing exploration experience in the Paterson Province (Red Setter, Cottesloe), showing technical competence. Financially able to undertake initial programs on the licence. No preferential weighting for large ASX-listed companies in a ballot: Even a large player like Antipa Minerals (ASX: AZY) had no extra advantage — in a ballot, all eligible applicants have an equal chance. Strategic implications: The WA government often encourages smaller explorers to operate in greenfield areas, because they are more likely to take early-stage exploration risk, whereas large miners may focus only on high-confidence targets. 3. Other Factors That Can Influence Awarding Even though it was a ballot, sometimes DMIRS considers: Factor	Effect Technical history in region	Companies with prior experience nearby (like Wishbone) show they can manage logistics, heritage, and land access. Environmental / heritage compliance	Existing heritage agreements (like Wishbone already has with Greatland Gold) reduce regulatory risk. Exploration plan realism	Smaller explorers often propose focused and staged drilling programs, which may be more manageable for government oversight. In this case, E45/7169 will be added to an existing access agreement with Greatland Gold, which could have strengthened Wishbone’s application over competitors who might not yet have access arrangements. 4. Why Larger Competitors Can Lose in a Ballot Random chance matters: The ballot is literally a lottery among eligible applicants, so even a company with a $500 M market cap has the same odds as a $50 M explorer.

data.author: Archangeleyes
data.content: There are some academic studies and research articles that look at how TikTok (and the short-form video format it popularises) may be associated with reduced attention spans, cognitive focus, and patience-related behaviours. Fast-paced content conditions the brain for quick rewards and novelty, which can reduce willingness to engage in longer, less stimulating tasks. Divided attention and increased cognitive load from short-form feeds may limit deep processing and focus. Now ask yourself an honest question are you watching too much tiktok and posting; "RNS TODAY" "UFO, GUARANTEED BAGGER TOMORROW" "WHERE IS MY £1.30" "BETTER NOT BE AN RNS ON A FRIDAY" "RNS TOMORROW" "I'VE GIVEN UP, I CAN BET YOU DL AND RP ARE HAVING GOLDEN SHOWERS TOGETHER IN DUBAI AT THE SHAREHOLDERS EXPENSE, BASTAARDS!" disclaimer: the above is satire and the allegations of dl and rp having golden showers in Dubai is just for humour and are not true.... Gla and enjoy your evening.

data.author: NettlesTheCat
data.content: What RNS are you waiting for?  Assay results?  Interview said clearly it would be Feb (so another 24 days to go to get the RNS) and even then it was considered to a non entity based on mining continuing from April. I suggest we look at the somewhat lacklustre interview and realise what they are clearly saying;  Assay results may come back OK, but either way, the knowledge they have of mining after April (if it's more assay or major drill) suggest to me that they know they have a Greatland site here. It's clear they weren't worried.  It's clear they had a smirk on both their faces all the way through. Imagine winning the lottery and not being able to announce that fact, but feeling smug as hell about what you have? That's where we are with WSBN, in my humble opinion, and movements at the moment are nothing more than a top up if they go low. Unless I'm being fooled of course?

data.author: The_Linns
data.content: That's a great post Archangeleyes.  And that's why it was very sensible for Wishbone to raise the £4m when they did (and at a much higher share price) as it means they are well funded to bridge the gap until they decide to announce the results / next stage in Red Setter development.  As well as the consolidation which provides Wishbone with plenty of optionality as well as a cleaner share register.  They have put the company in a very robust position during this critical development stage.

data.author: Archangeleyes
data.content: My thoughts is that Poulden did not like the pumping of the sp and was worried that upon releasing the grades of holes 1 and 2 (lets assume they are class) would result in a pump and dump, before he was ready to gather the rest of the data, organise permission of the road, consolidate, plan the next drill and raise capital on a sp that has already sailed on him then promptly drifted before the optimal price to raise capital. By working with ALS to collate all the assays before release stopped the sp from pumping, allowed it to drift. He will announce the news when he has his ducks in a row to act. This is the correct order of business as we will already be looking forward to the next drill plan and anticipation of a buyout/jv if this is another telfer. data.author: howezap
data.content: This initial drill phase of the ‘deeper’ anomalous EM  survey signatures that they are testing now, are reconnaissance in nature. They are more to understand the mineralisation with the data from them used to update the geological model that is overlayed with all the previous ground and air survey data to ‘then’ be able to more accurately target grade and continuity better in later rounds. The geological team would not expect to hit high grade mineralisation first time round, it is not the purpose of recon drilling to chase high grades. So shareholders should certainly not expect them to be high grading over long intercepts without this initial data to be able to interpret the geo model. This is standard normal stuff and essential to get best value per metre of drill core over the coarse of the programme. It is fact that most geologists dont hit any mineralisation with first one or two sighters, but rest assured every single new hole gives invaluable information to the modellers. All the best.

data.author: howezap
data.content: This initial drill phase of the ‘deeper’ anomalous EM  survey signatures that they are testing now, are reconnaissance in nature. They are more to understand the mineralisation with the data from them used to update the geological model that is overlayed with all the previous ground and air survey data to ‘then’ be able to more accurately target grade and continuity better in later rounds. The geological team would not expect to hit high grade mineralisation first time round, it is not the purpose of recon drilling to chase high grades. So shareholders should certainly not expect them to be high grading over long intercepts without this initial data to be able to interpret the geo model. This is standard normal stuff and essential to get best value per metre of drill core over the coarse of the programme. It is fact that most geologists dont hit any mineralisation with first one or two sighters, but rest assured every single new hole gives invaluable information to the modellers. All the best.

data.content: Courtesy of Afzal on x Would be boom White Mountain Gold/Silver Project not priced in 👇 We are forgetting the value of @WishboneGoldPlc White Mountain Project, adjacent property mineralization was valued at $2bn before the gold/silver rise Who much would the value be now 😮 A number of companies have been active in the general area. The first group consisted of the early miners of the 1800s and early to mid-1900s. The early explorers identified areas that remain of particular interest to present day exploration companies. These efforts were based on surface sampling and drilling to limited depths. Given the recent revival of gold prices many prospects are now being revisited. The significance of the historical workings and recent exploration activities adjacent to White Mountain is that recognised shear zones in granite appear to be trending into the White Mountain EPM, especially in the southwest areas. This indicates the shear zones that occur in White Mountain are primary targets for follow-up exploration. The adjacent property reportedly hosts a JORC-compliant resource of 79,000oz of gold and 1.5m oz of silver located wholly within a 600m portion of a single, mineralised shear zone.  The suggested target below the resource identified to date is projected by others to be about 350,000 tonnes amounting to more than one million oz gold and 21 million oz of silver or, assuming current precious metals prices, more than US$2bn in place, should such mineralisation be confirmed during drilling. This suggests that the White Mountain EPM offers favourable conditions for significant mineralisation of not only gold and silver, but also for other metals as well

data.author: Aimingtoplease
data.content: The silence feels like someone is doing their due diligence , smells like a takeover/jv on the horizon

1️⃣ How rising gold prices can delay assay releases When gold prices rise sharply: Increased drilling activity across the sector → labs get swamped with samples. This is especially true for juniors doing deep core drilling. Priority shifts → larger producers may pay for fast-track assays, so smaller juniors’ results can be delayed. Logistics → deeper holes generate more core, which takes longer to cut, prep, and send for assay. Quality control & verification → labs may take extra time to ensure accuracy because high-value results are more market-sensitive. Bottom line: even if drilling is complete, market and lab conditions can stretch the time to public release by several weeks to a few months. 2️⃣ Effect on Wishbone Gold’s 2025 Red Setter campaign Key dates: Drilling started 21 July 2025 Hole 2 completed mid-October 2025 (~950 m) Core dispatched for assay mid‑October Under normal lab conditions: assays would likely take 6–10 weeks, meaning results could have been expected late November to early December 2025. With the recent gold price surge: Labs may be backlogged, particularly for deep diamond core. Processing time could extend by 4–6 weeks, pushing preliminary results to late December 2025 – mid-January 2026. Follow-up, collated results for additional holes may not be released until February 2026 or later, depending on lab throughput. 3️⃣ Comparison with Greatland Gold (Paterson South) Greatland’s initial deep drilling (maiden campaign) ran late June → November 2023, with results out ~4½ months after drilling start. At that time, the gold price was lower and drilling demand was moderate, so lab turnaround was more predictable. If Greatland had faced a similar price-driven surge in assay demand, the 4–5 month timeline might have slipped to 5–6 months before results were released. Implication for Wishbone: the recent gold price surge is likely delaying their results relative to the baseline Greatland timeline, meaning initial results could arrive 1–2 months later than they otherwise would have, especially for deep holes.

data.content: With junior gold miners, bad news is typically released quickly—often before all assays have returned from the laboratory, ensuring timely disclosure to the market. They do not delay reporting while awaiting outstanding results. In parallel, the company continues to advance key corporate and operational initiatives, including: •	Applied for 12 new adjoining exploration licences, a clear move to lock up prospective ground and prevent competitors from pegging around the core project •	Share consolidation undertaken to tidy up the capital structure and improve trading efficiency, which is common at this stage of a junior’s lifecycle •	Ongoing share register housekeeping aimed at removing legacy issues from earlier capital raisings and improving administrative efficiency •	Application has been lodged for a new access road licence, which is a practical requirement for sustained drilling and field work rather than a cosmetic exercise •	The company continues to work through permitting, environmental, and stakeholder engagement processes required to advance exploration •	Technical work is ongoing, including data review, target refinement, and planning of follow-up programs based on results to date

data.author: Paddylogic
data.content: The short, cosmic version: most of the gold on Earth was forged in violent space events, long before our planet existed. Here’s the breakdown 👇 🌌 Born in space Gold is too heavy to be made in ordinary stars. It forms during extreme explosions where tons of neutrons are flying around, mainly: Neutron star collisions (two ultra-dense dead stars smashing together) Some supernovae (massive star explosions) In those moments, atoms slam together and build heavy elements like gold, platinum, and uranium. ☄️ Delivered to Earth When Earth first formed, it was molten. Most gold sank toward the core. The gold we can actually mine today likely came later via asteroid and meteorite impacts during Earth’s early history, which sprinkled gold into the crust. ⛏️ Concentrated by Earth Over billions of years: Volcanoes Hot underground fluids Plate tectonics …moved and concentrated tiny amounts of gold into veins and deposits that humans eventually found and mined. ✨ The cool takeaway Every gold ring, coin, or nugget you’ve ever seen is made of atoms that were: Created in a cataclysmic space event Older than the Earth Literally stardust If you want, I can go deeper into the physics, the geology, or the history of how humans first found and used gold. Now if Tefler was hit by a meteor and Haverion, then is not unlikely that Wishbone was in the same meteor shower except our meteor was bigger.

data.author: Bigw77
data.content: I'm feeling like game time is on the horizon. 1 - Lenigas (love him or hate him) is on his way to Oz, for WSBN and others. He's interested in making money 2 - The assays ARE NOT DELAYED, they have told us they are not delayed. They have also said that they want to collect all of the results, not just the ones that they already have and formulate a wider plan. Makes sense to me. 3 - Lenigas raison d'etre is two things, increase SP and raise cash. As that is the cvase, timing is everything for us. We are back at a low point, its not now (IMHO) going back to he 70's). Buy now and enjoy the spoils, take care though, I will only be selling above 100p, not buying, a view that might change if circumstances change, but thats where I am right now. 4 - Poulden doesn't give a monkeys if gold comes out of the ground, he will be in the ground before the gold comes out of it. These things take inordinate amounts of time, and he's not getting any younger. So, the focus here will be about generating cash in his pockets. Two ways of that happening Option A - he is a shareholder too, so it could very well be through some kind of JV, very likely with GGP (I don't buy the Nifty copper story, that's just a play to give GGP the impression that there is more than one interested organisation, and Nifty gave them an eff off pill with their robjection to the road). GGP will be acutely aware that they are really the only option for WSBN, and so they won't want to overpay for WSBN. Option B - further raises. Anybody that thinks that WSBN won't raise again is deluded, you need cash to push these things along, you need cash to explore, you most certainly need cash to get gold out of the ground. My full expectation is that the SP will go back to 150p in the next 6 weeks, they will then raise. Later this year we will be looking at a JV with GGP. That JV (depending upon the results of all of the assays) will be closer to £3 value to WSBN. Take whatever I've said with a pinch of salt, its the musings of an investor who does his research, however, the RNS from Friday last week took me very much by surprise. If nothing else the ride with WSBN is entertaining, lets just hope that its rewarding too. For goodness sake, do your own research, careful of who you listen to on here. Definitely don't simply rely upon the kudos of a premium member, I am aware of at least one person on here who regularly states what L2 is doing, and when I check its a pack of lies.

data.author: TheBasher
data.content: I asked ChatGPT; “ for a junior gold mining company does a delay in the release of assay results normally indicate good or bad results? Or what does it signify? Bottom line A delay in assay results: ❌ Does not reliably signal bad grades ❌ Does not reliably signal good grades ✅ Usually signals lab congestion, QA/QC verification, or reporting strategy The only time a delay becomes meaningful is when: It is repeated and unexplained; It coincides with financing difficulties; Management communication becomes evasive. Otherwise, it’s just normal exploration logistics.

data.author: justcause
data.content: Wonder what our other projects are worth now given the price of gold and silver 🤔 Exploration Assets Wishbone Gold's key exploration properties are located across Western Australia and Queensland. Red Setter Project: The flagship project located in the Patersons Range region of Western Australia, prospective for Havieron-style gold deposits. Cottesloe Project: Located southeast of Red Setter, this project shows visible deposits of silver and lead. Anketell Project: Consists of a single exploration license application covering over 10 square kilometers in Western Australia. White Mountain Project: Located in Queensland, this asset includes historical polymetallic mines. Wishbone II, IV, and VI Projects: These exploration licenses are in the Mingela-Charters Towers region in Queensland, an area known for significant precious metal mineralization.

Why These Examples Matter for Red Setter Based on the Australian precedent: •	Extended drilling followed by delayed assay results has precedent for companies that later released positive discoveries (e.g., Australian Mines). •	Delays do not necessarily indicate poor results — they often reflect operational and reporting strategy priorities common in deep exploration programs. •	Conversely, delays for projects with entirely negative outcomes often either (a) announce disappointing results quickly to reset market expectations, or (b) pivot to new targets — rather than staying in extended silence. ________________________________________ Summary Yes — there are Australian exploration examples where elongated assay timelines were followed by strong results. The Australian Mines Boa Vista program (ASX:AUZ) is the clearest recent analogue: deep drilling, delayed assays for a large batch of holes, and then very positive broad gold intercepts reported once multiple assays were ready

data.author: Armchairtrading
data.content: That's a lots of 7's there....but not WSBN so please go elsewhere!

Before core samples are sent to the lab, a 1-metre core is cut in 2 vertically. If high values are discovered it is normal for the re-testing to be done, often mandatory and the 2nd sample is generally dispatched to another lab.

🧠 Key Points — Complexity & Challenges 📊 Complexity Sample prep is the most labour-intensive. Fire assay requires precision, especially with trace metals. QC is crucial and sometimes iterative. ⏱ Time Impacts Lab backlogs can extend turnaround times significantly. Explorers often schedule shipments to balance speed and cost. 🔁 Re-Testing High values often must be re-assayed for confirmation. Multiple assays reduce risk of false positives.

data.author: Paddylogic
data.content: The short, cosmic version: most of the gold on Earth was forged in violent space events, long before our planet existed. Here’s the breakdown 👇 🌌 Born in space Gold is too heavy to be made in ordinary stars. It forms during extreme explosions where tons of neutrons are flying around, mainly: Neutron star collisions (two ultra-dense dead stars smashing together) Some supernovae (massive star explosions) In those moments, atoms slam together and build heavy elements like gold, platinum, and uranium. ☄️ Delivered to Earth When Earth first formed, it was molten. Most gold sank toward the core. The gold we can actually mine today likely came later via asteroid and meteorite impacts during Earth’s early history, which sprinkled gold into the crust. ⛏️ Concentrated by Earth Over billions of years: Volcanoes Hot underground fluids Plate tectonics …moved and concentrated tiny amounts of gold into veins and deposits that humans eventually found and mined. ✨ The cool takeaway Every gold ring, coin, or nugget you’ve ever seen is made of atoms that were: Created in a cataclysmic space event Older than the Earth Literally stardust If you want, I can go deeper into the physics, the geology, or the history of how humans first found and used gold. Now if Tefler was hit by a meteor and Haverion, then is not unlikely that Wishbone was in the same meteor shower except our meteor was bigger.

data.author: Bigw77
data.content: I'm feeling like game time is on the horizon. 1 - Lenigas (love him or hate him) is on his way to Oz, for WSBN and others. He's interested in making money 2 - The assays ARE NOT DELAYED, they have told us they are not delayed. They have also said that they want to collect all of the results, not just the ones that they already have and formulate a wider plan. Makes sense to me. 3 - Lenigas raison d'etre is two things, increase SP and raise cash. As that is the cvase, timing is everything for us. We are back at a low point, its not now (IMHO) going back to he 70's). Buy now and enjoy the spoils, take care though, I will only be selling above 100p, not buying, a view that might change if circumstances change, but thats where I am right now. 4 - Poulden doesn't give a monkeys if gold comes out of the ground, he will be in the ground before the gold comes out of it. These things take inordinate amounts of time, and he's not getting any younger. So, the focus here will be about generating cash in his pockets. Two ways of that happening Option A - he is a shareholder too, so it could very well be through some kind of JV, very likely with GGP (I don't buy the Nifty copper story, that's just a play to give GGP the impression that there is more than one interested organisation, and Nifty gave them an eff off pill with their robjection to the road). GGP will be acutely aware that they are really the only option for WSBN, and so they won't want to overpay for WSBN. Option B - further raises. Anybody that thinks that WSBN won't raise again is deluded, you need cash to push these things along, you need cash to explore, you most certainly need cash to get gold out of the ground. My full expectation is that the SP will go back to 150p in the next 6 weeks, they will then raise. Later this year we will be looking at a JV with GGP. That JV (depending upon the results of all of the assays) will be closer to £3 value to WSBN. Take whatever I've said with a pinch of salt, its the musings of an investor who does his research, however, the RNS from Friday last week took me very much by surprise. If nothing else the ride with WSBN is entertaining, lets just hope that its rewarding too. For goodness sake, do your own research, careful of who you listen to on here. Definitely don't simply rely upon the kudos of a premium member, I am aware of at least one person on here who regularly states what L2 is doing, and when I check its a pack of lies.
